Here is a summary of what happened before: What I've learned in relation to the user's request:

- The paper discusses a novel continuous electrochemical carbon-capture technology using a modular solid-electrolyte reactor.
- The technology operates with renewable electricity and addresses issues of low capture rates, oxygen sensitivity, and system complexity in existing carbon capture methods.
- The reactor design couples oxygen/water (O2/H2O) redox electrolysis for efficient CO2 absorption at the cathode-membrane interface, forming carbonate ions.
- A high-purity (>99%) CO2 stream is continuously outputted from the middle solid-electrolyte layer without the need for chemical inputs or generation of side products.

- Information on the migration of carbonate ions across the anion-exchange membrane (AEM) into the porous solid-electrolyte (PSE) layer.
- Details on how the protons (H+) generated at the anode travel across the cation-exchange membrane (CEM) and recombine with carbonate ions to form CO2 gas.
- A description of the advantages of the solid-electrolyte carbon-capture design over other electrochemical carbon-capture methods.
- An explanation of how the triple-phase boundary at the cathode enhances CO2 diffusion and capture efficiency.
- Insights into how the technology leverages advancements in fuel cells and water splitting catalysts for high energy efficiency and scalability.
- A summary of the continuous, simultaneous, and integrated carbon-capture and release process that distinguishes this technology from traditional absorption/desorption cycles.
- Any additional results, discussions, or conclusions presented in the remaining sections of the paper that were not covered in the read chunks.
